North, South, East, West, Left, Right, Up, Down are all relative to a known/established reference.
Each one is not a dimension.
However, they may describe a dimension and rotational direction.

Every dimension has a distance and direction(2 complementary).

Any departure from the direction of Dimension requires the reference of the other dimensions that crossed(entered).

A straight line is 1D (example unit: cm)
An area is a 2D (unit example: cm2)
A volume is 3D (example of unit: cm3)

What is the unit of 4D, 5D; etc?

The diameter and radius of a circle is 1D.
The circumference of a circle is 1D.

The area under a curved line, thus a circle is 1D.

The imagination may be considered a dimension but it is NOT a geometrical dimension!

An abstraction is NOT a geometrical dimension.

Geometrical dimension is related to shapes, their dimension, angle.

A rotation of such shape does not establish another dimension.
Rather, it only alters the instantaneous perspective (illusional).

The human eyes is limited to see three dimensions only.

Maybe it's better to say there is a fourth dimension, but that it doesn't necessarily have to be time - it just depends what order you choose to label them. (Or even if you choose to label them in a way that allows ordering things in a systematic way.)
There are (at least) four dimensions, but you can talk about them in any order. We label 3 spatial dimensions as the first three, and the 1 temporal dimension the fourth, by (unspoken) convention. (And because we grow up hearing time referred to as 'the fourth dimension')

The convention came about because time wasn't academically considered to be a dimension until after the three spatial ones were. Somewhere between Newton and Einstein (I think), time went from something that exists but you don't really think about, to just another axis on a graph.

Einstein was the first to think about time as being 'like' space, a dimension (or axis) you can move forwards and backwards on, and trace out wiggly paths through spacetime, rather than just through space. Even the words we use to talk about time 'forwards and backwards' suggest that there is only one way to travel through it, in a straight line, and that's mostly true in every-day experience, but it turns out not to be completely true if you look closely enough. For instance, GPS satellites need to take relativity into account in order to work accurately.

Learning in school now, children generally learn (formally) about 2 spatial dimensions (doing geometry on the x-y cartesian plane), add in a temporal dimension (learning about motion with constant acceleration using suvat) and then if they continue studying physics/maths, add in a third spatial dimension using vector notation.

Yes, there is. Your basis for that statement is ridiculous. The first dimension is always width relative to your frame of reference. There is a difference. If we are moving on the surface of a globe, we have two degrees - or dimensions - of freedom. Of course then we also move in a third dimension, but there is no degree of freedom in this third dimension. We have three dimensions of freedom in space, but we cannot move in space without moving in the 4th time dimension and we cannot move backwards in 4th dimension. Dimensions can have different shape, curvature and properties, even in pure mathematics.

Lol man ... Dimension means "measure". There are infinite possible "dimensions". Now, in describing how to measure reality itself, we are talking about matter. Matter is simply measured at its Height x Width x Length (3 dimensions), and its behavior is really limited to these dimensional orientations ... simple as that ... Time is a dimension (a MEASURE) used to calculate a property of the space itself (the time taken to travel the space between 2 reference points). This "dimension" is not the same as describing the dimensions of reality (of matter), it describes only one property of the space.

When we say the fourth dimension we mean the one additional dimension, since we have 3 dimensions and they are named in order: length, then width, and then height. This is just plain wrong. The 4D Rubik's cube example is specious.
If you want to imagine 4 dimensions it's simple.
First let's simplify and think about one dimension, X. Now let's visualize a point in the X dimension. Imagine it's X dimension coordinate is 5. Then imagine it's 10. The units don't matter and you intuitively know that the point is now twice as far from the origin at 10 as it was at 5.
Now let's imagine the same thing in two dimensions. Our point starts at X=5, Y=0. Then imagine it at X=10, Y=0. To us this looks no different than the first example because we didn't move in the Y dimension, but that doesn't mean there is no Y dimension, we just don't see it implicitly because our point isn't moving in it.
OK, so let's take the example all the way, skipping the third dimension and imagining the outcome was the same in three dimensions and skip to four dimensions.
In this case let's first imagine our point only moves in the fourth dimension, time. In the first three dimensions it appears stationary. It is moving through time but not space. Now let's move it in two dimensions at once. Let's move it along the X axis and the Time axis. Think of a chart or graph. For each unit of time we move, the point moves 5 units of X. What do we see? Well, at unit 0 of Time, the point is at X=5, Y=0, Z=0. At unit 1 of Time, our point is at X=10, Y=0, Z-0, Time=1. At unit 2 of Time, it's X=15, Y=0, Z=0, Time=2.
Our perception of this is MOTION and it's one of the ways we perceive Time (or at least interpret it). But simply looked at the point is moving in two of the four dimensions. X and Time. Nothing difficult here. The only difference is that we can only move in the positive direction on the time axis, as far as we know anyway. It's like a one way street. Different, but not hard to grasp.

I disagree with the notion of the example that a cup, once mixed with another cup, becomes indistinguishable or intermingled beyond comprehension. The individual particulates of the original cup still exist and can still be discerned from the second cup (at least in theory, in practice this would be near impossible given the scale and current technology). What I mean is that even after you have poured two cups, you are free to begin segregating the first from the second or third through any methodology you wish, such as modeling the atomic behavior of the system or observing the occupancy of each molecule of water and noting interactivity.

Dimensions have nothing to do with direction. They are relevant to the usage of space. We actually live in the fourth dimension, which is why we perceive three dimensional objects as being the highest form of creation. If we lived in the third dimension, we would perceive two dimensional objects as the highest form of creation and so forth. That water and oil in a jug explanation has nothing to do with dimensions, but everything to do with physical properties. Math is an irrefutable truth of the universe. In math when you plot a line, it is a second dimensional object in within the third dimension. The line travels along the X,Y plain, because it is two dimensional. However, if the line could talk it would not perceive this, the same way we do, because we can see it going either vertical, horizontal or a combination of both or we could rotate the line into traveling along the X,Y, and Z plane. But to the line itself, none of that would matter, because it is simply a line going in one direction. Add to that, the line may not even see itself as a line. Let's think about this. When we view anything with our eyes all we see at one moment are combination of two dimensional planes that seem to form three dimensional objects. Never, unless we are looking at a transparent object do we see the entire object at once and even then all we can see is the direct viewpoint we are looking at the object from. However, if we could perceive four dimensions while existing in the fifth we could perceive the entire three dimensional object at once and all sides at the same time. Now, I know that doesn't seem possible, to most. But, if you could talk to a line, a cube wouldn't make much sense to it either. Because, all a line knows is back and forth without knowing if that back and forth is up, down, in or out.

I've heard time and again people arguing with each other over "what is the fourth dimension?" and "is time the fourth dimension?" These questions only make sense when you agree to label the dimensions of space time in a certain order, at which point the answer to "what is the fourth dimension" is obvious: it's whatever you just agreed to call the fourth dimension! We know that there are four (3 spatial + 1 time) dimensions, but it is meaningless to speculate on what THE fourth (or first or third...) is unless it is in reference to some naming convention.

No, we do have 4 spatial dimensions.
Experienced as, up/down, left/right, back/forward, and time/anti-time(or future/past).
We can only directly experience the fourth spatial dimension as time because we only go in one direction along it.  Atomic and sub-atomic "particles" are sometimes capable of temporally traveling in the opposite direction along it (to the past).
Anti-matter has the opposite property, it usually travels backwards (to us), anti-time (the past). 

Time is caused by the expansion of the universe along the fourth spatial dimension, as well as the other three dimensions.

It's a theory as in M-theory.  We can do thought experiments and use virtual reality software to visualize 4-D objects and how they behave in 4-D spatially and through time.  Just like we can depict 3-D objects in 2-D in Flatland.  That said, it's difficult to think how a Flatlander can recognize another Flatlander when all they see are different lines for different objects.  It's assumed that the can recognize each other somehow because a 3-D object can recognize another 3-D object.  Thus, we won't recognize a true 4-D object and how it behaves except visualize it in 3-D.  We can angle the object so it shows a different view and we can depict it in 3-D.  With virtual reality software, we can show how a 4-D object such as a hypercube or Tesseract behaves in 4-D spatially.  We can show it as it goes through time, as well.  To show the 4th dimension exists, we are trying to find how a graviton particle acts using the LHC.  If we can show it disappears, then it may be evidence of a 4th dimension.

This is exactly how general relativity works. In it, the universe does indeed have four dimensions, but it is not in general possible to divide them up cleanly in a given coordinate system. For instance, there are moving coordinates for black holes called Eddington-Finkelstein coordinates in which the standard Schwarzschild time and space coordinates are mixed together. Because of that mixing, the new Eddington-Finkelstein coordinates can not be subdivided into simply time or space coordinates. All that one can say in the most general space-time is that the metric tensor will have three positive eigenvalues (corresponding to three spatial degrees of freedom) and one negative eigenvalue (one timelike degree of freedom).

Of course it does. From the standpoint of linear algebra, you are locating points on a given vector space using a vector base, and bases are ordered sets, by definition. The point (0,0,0,1) is different from the point (1,0,0,0),  so the order of dimensions matter and there is, indeed, a fourth dimension. Of course you could change the vector base by a base change operation, but in that new vector base there would still be order, which means that looking to the vector base there is a first, a second, a third dimension, and so forth. Jesus most of you guys have no idea what he's talking about, not to be pretentious or anything. What he's saying is that there is a difference between a SPATIAL dimension and  a TEMPORAL dimension. When you look at a 4d cube or a tesseract (or at least it's shadow) you're looking at the 3d representation of an object with 4 spatial dimensions. A temporal dimension would dictate how matter and entropy move in a space. When people from whatever scientific discipline  talk about spacetime, they mean that we have 3 spatial dimensions and one time dimension. There could be another universe where there's 5 spatial dimensions and one time, or there could be one with 7 spatial and 3 time dimensions. It's a pretty common idea in physics that many people agree on.

you dont assign the title of first, second third, etc... for no reason. its called the point line plane postulate. you imagine your dimension at its largest possible size (for the first dimension that would look like an infinitely long line with no height and no width, so it can be thought of as 2 point with an orientation in space that are connected.) then to imagine the next dimension up you must be able to find a point that is not on the original spacial axis. so if we wanted to create the second dimension we would simply imagine a point above or below that line and join it with a line that intersects the first axis, that is the second dimension. dimensions arent named by their orientation in space, they're named after how many axes you have access to. also time doesn't behave different than the other dimensions, its simply you cannot observe the dimension you are in, only those below you. we need to move along an axis of time to be able to experience three dimensions, imagine the universe without four spacial dimensions, you could not travel across the fourth, therefore the universe would not evolve. if the fourth dimension ceased to exist at this very moment how would you know objects have 3 spacial dimensions, it takes time for you to rotate an object for you to confirm its 3d, it takes time for you to walk to the other side of a building an experience the perspective shift, to confirm it has a width and not just height and length. the 4th dimension is a spacial dimension, and you can assign the title of first, second third etc... dimensions without it being irrelevant.

I disagree with this. There IS in fact a fourth dimension, and a third, and a second, and a first. It's not very accurate to relate them to cups of water, because in water everything molds together into one fluid body. In dimensions, however, there are requirements to achieve a certain dimensional existence- namely, the ones before it. If I were to draw a cube, I would first need to make a line, then a plane by intersecting those lines, then a space by intersecting those planes. Assuming the fourth dimension deals with time, that cube doesn't exist in four dimensions- it is still and exists in three. There is no matter of 'direction,' because dimensions go in ALL directions. If you start with a line, you can point it in infinitely many directions and it will still be a one-dimensional line in the first dimension. However, the moment you intersect that line with another, it creates the concept of a flat space called a plane- that is, several lines can exist in different positions throughout. As soon as you intersect that 'plane' with another, you get a space- multiple planes can exist within that space, and thus a third dimension is formed. In two dimensions, could you have a separate plane anywhere in existence? No. In one dimension, could you have anything but one line in existence? No. Thus, you need all dimensions before it to achieve the dimension your object exists in. It's not a matter of direction, but a matter of quantity- as soon as you have more than one dimensional concept in dimension n, it must exist in a dimension higher than n.

This video assumes reality exists on Cartesian axes, which it doesn't. The three actual dimensions are line space (north-south), plane space (east-west; equatorial), gravity space (from space, toward the core) and each opens up an order of magnitude of possible arrangements of that before it, and is therefore infinitely bigger (plane space cannot be simulated in line space, and gravity space cannot be simulated in plane space). Time is a measure of solar system relativity, so too is the Cartesian coordinate system and 3D perspective. You could say that collapsing nebulae have many dimensions, whereas a simple 1-2-3 is what you expect see from a stable, unchanging object (it's a physical minimum, and it sums all influence).

I don't think there's direct proof that the time dimension is different than the other ones. Just because Entropy seems to have a fixed direction in our local Universe, that doesn't mean it will be like that throughout the Universe. Einstein himself believed that time is just like the other three dimensions, and that our sense of time 'passing' is an illusion.

Another theory on why there is no 4th dimension. A dimension is not a universe that we live in, rather the way we see things. Therefore, if you look at a Rubik's cube from the perfect angle from the side, you can only see a square, hence 2d square, or 2d triangle, or 2d whatever the case may be. Human eyes are only capable of seeing 3 dimensional figures because, we can not see through something, unless it is glass, and even if it is glass it would have to double and maybe even triple for it to be considered 4d, so in that case a pentagon, would have well over a hundred sides outside, and if you had special eyes to see through it, hundreds more lines and sides that overlapped each other on the inside of the million sided 4d pentagon. Also dimensions are the direction you are going. In 2d, you would only be able to move North, South, East, and West, plus you wouldn't be able to flip over so you would be looking at one side of the world upside down. In 3d we can move up, down, north, south, east, and west. So in theory, if there was a fourth dimension somehow, the moment we entered it we would turn inside out and make a huge mess of inner organs on the 4d floor and the 4d sofa. There is no other way of direction, you can't move diagonally naturally, and even then diagonal is a direction, if you did manage to move another direction and see things from a 4d perspective, your body would be incapable of seeing the 4d objects and your sense of sight would vanish, which is the scientific way of saying that your eyeballs would explode. There is no 4d of seeing and there is no 4th direction to move. Therefore, technically there is no 3D, or 2d, or 4d, or zero. But if you were to apply this logic to 3d space, it would mean "up" is one dimension and "down" another.  This would mean that we live in 6 spatial dimensions and 1 time dimension. I would like to submit a challenge and say that "time" is really just a spatial dimension. There are not 3 spatial dimensions and 1 time dimension, they are all just spatial dimensions. It seems inconsistent and a nuisance to have one wacky wierd-O dimension that doesn't act like the rest. I can explain how I see it as a spatial dimension. Have you ever seen one of those flip books where you flip through all the pages rapidly and an animation can be seen? I posit that our universe is very much like that. Where one page in that book is like a slice of frozen time in our world, just like one page is a slice of frozen time for the animation. On closer inspection you can see that animation has a "world line" and it is actually a 3 dimensional object. The same I think is true of us. Our perception of time is just a flip book if you will in layman's terms. Where the book is 4 dimensional  and the page is a 3 dimensional slice of frozen time in our world. As we move through this 4 dimensional space we get the illusion of time as we flip from one page to the next. I don't really believe we are in a 4 dimensional book but I thought it best to illustrate the concept this way. So as you can see, time isn't spooky or different at all. It is just a higher spatial dimension like all the rest. Just like the 3 dimensional book gives the two dimensional animation the illusion of time.

one could argue that time is a dimension, since the 2nd dimension is infinite instances of the 1st dimension stacked together.  Then the 3rd dimension is infinite instances of 2nd dimensions stacked together.  So the 4th dimension would be infinite instances of the third dimension stacked together.  As 3 dimensional beings, the 4th dimension is more of a concept than a reality, and as time and space are instances of the same thing, one could hypothesize that your sense of time is the integral or perhaps derivative of your current dimension.This would make sense, as multiple instances of the first dimension to a one dimensional creature would be more of a concept than a reality. But we know that each instance of the creature moving exists separately, and an infinite amount of those instances would make the second dimension.

Let's make a thought experiment. Imagine your car has a system that has a Long'GPS (a GPS that only describes longitude) + a Lat'GPS (a GPS that only describes latitude) + an Altimeter (describes Altitude or Height).

You drive for days, and go to a very high parking, maybe several kilometers high. You park your car at a random level in the parking, very high. Then there is a blast of EMP and all your electronics get knocked down, and you get kicked in the head and forget everything. When you'll be looking for your car, what do you need to do to find it?

You will get a look at the coordinates the 2 GPS and Altimer displays (it's locked since the time of the EMP blast). Each device gives you a 1-dimensional information.
- The GPS give you the latitude and longitude. It means both GPS provide 1-dimensional information about the position. It's a first dimension. But you are clever and you combine these two data points: at the cross of these 2 one-dimensional lines, there is the 2-dimensional position of your car on Earth's surface. It is the 2nd dimension.
- Then, Altimeter gives you the height of your car. You combine GPS + Altimer: your car is at the cross of the 2-dimensional position (latitude+longitude) and the 3rd line, the height, or distance from the 2D position of your car on Earth's surface. The third dimension (because it's a 3rd number to describe the coordinates).
- You go to this exact 3-dimensional position (longitude+latitude+height). Your car is not here. Why?

Because you forgot THE FOURTH dimension: time. Indeed, you just woke up from a 25-year long coma. Your car has been stolen. Time IS the 4th dimension. Because it ADDS a 4th number to describe the coordinates of your car. The position of your car changed in time. And only by looking at this 4th dimension you can find your car.
"Where was my car 25 years ago at 10am?" This is a 1D coordinate because there is just 1 number (the date), but if you can add to this the 2 GPS + Altimeter's coordinates, and if you can time-travel as easily as you can space-travel, you would find it back right here in the parking lot 25 years ago.

So there is a FIRST dimension (one line, wherever it comes from and goes to, be it north, up, back, or left) and then a second, and a third and a fourth dimension. And we humans are able to tell which one is which. The author of this vid is confusing spacetime dimensions with playing with a compass in his head. The space dimensions are just not about right/left or up/down or back and forth or north, est, west, south. A dimension is about the minimum number of coordinates (number) required to describe the position of any point within it. In this world, we need 4 numbers (or data point) to describe the position of any point / object because we live in a 4 dimensional world. Now how do we know Time is the 4th?

What's the minimum number of coordinates you need to describe the position of a point within Time? 1. So it can in theory be the first dimension. But we had our Einstein moments so now we know the space and time are not separate, just as we know earth is not flat. So what's the minimum number of coordinates you need to describe the position of a point within spaceTIME (when you add time)? 4. Time adds the 4th coordinates required to describe the position of a point within spacetime. So it is the 4th dimension.

So... your argument is entirely reliant on the assumption that we are incapable of distinguishing which dimensions come in which order... when mathematicians have clearly laid this out for us. Granted you could have your dimension of length in any direction orthogonal to your direction of width, and you can have your dimension of depth in any orthogonal direction that agrees with the cross product of your length and width, but that doesn't change the fact that they are numbered as the first, second and third. Width is reliant on a length, depth is reliant on a cross-sectional area defined by length and width, and time ( that fourth dimension you claim doesn't exist ) is the basis upon which we can distinguish the three special dimensions. My point being that you may think it is arbitrary to call it a fourth dimension, when in actuality and according to mathematical principles, our world would not make sense if depth came after time. The fourth dimension is much more simple than people think, especially since the fourth dimension is a made-up concept. He even shows the fourth dimension when he draws two cubes.

To get a second dimension from a first, you just create a stack of your first dimension, which converts a line into a two-dimensional graph. If you want a third dimension, you just stack your two-dimensional graphs, like a stack of paper, on top of one another.

In fact, if you do any programming it's easier to 'picture' it. You can also think of the first dimension as a line of text in a book, while the second dimension is stacks of lines on top of one another. Thees stacks give you pages, which you might consider the second dimension (or you could consider each chapter the second), and then you can think of multiple pages (or multiple chapters) as the third dimension. All you have to do is decide what you want your dimensions to consist of and be consistent.

We can not currently tell our 3 spatial dimensions appart, which is a good thing, because it means our universe is spatially isotropic. But mathematically and even physically there is nothing to suggest that every conceiveable universe (lorentzian or even more general pseudo riemannian metric manifold) should have this isotropy (equality of directions). For instance the Stringtheory you shortly hinted at with its multitude of spatial dimensions is not isotropic in a very weird way: we know from experiment that there are no large "normal" spatial extradimensions, because when we observe events with random direction distributions like particle collisions, we see no missing components.
Assume you let something explode, the debris flies of in all directions, if there were more than 3 spatial dimensions with the known properties, some of that stuff should fly away in those directions and be missing from our 3d space.

Maybe there are really weird physical rules preventing ordinary matter from translation along those other spatial dimensions, but then the string theory would get into trouble that proposed them in the first place, so that doesn't fix the problem.
What we can do instead is: assume that those dimensions are not open ("infinitely long" or "with no end") but closed, then they would have a finite volume, and every "energy content" to large to fit in there, just wouldnt go in. 

We have quite decent upper bounds of the sizes of those spatial extradimensions, if they exist. Then we can with certainty distinguish those extra spatial dimensions from our known 3 spatial dimensions. 

And that is why, if there are actually more than 3 spatial dimensions, it makes sense to distinguish them, opposite to what the video suggested.

The "fourth" dimension is not a misconception at all. Here is what is going on... If we had only 2 dimensions, living in "flatland" for example, "time" for us would be the 3rd dimension, or, our 2 dimensions plus another one. That "other one" would be so special for us in that 2d world that it would require a more specified name thus the "third" dimension. That's why we refer to the fourth dimension as the "fourth" dimension because it really is the "fourth" one to us. Its the one that is responsible for our "time" illusion. If we had 4 dimensions the fourth one wouldn't make any big difference to us cuz it would be exactly as typical as the other 3 would. But the 5th dimension to us then would be the "fifth" one because it would be responsible for our illusion of time ath the 4d reality (that is, if we where 4d, time for us would be the 5th one). So yeah. For us humans here at the 3d reality the "fourth" dimension really is a big deal and it really required to be more specific than the other 3. :)

Add time to any dimension, and you get the next dimension. Add time to a dot. It moves. Track its movement, and you get one dimension. Add time to that line, and it turns into two dimensions. It's just taking different versions of a model and fusing them together into one shape going in a different direction. Problem is, we don't know what direction to add to a 3D object. This is part of the reason people represent gravitational warps on spacetime as a bent flat sheet. We can represent the warp on time by pretending the "4th dimension" is the "3rd dimension" and the 3 spatial dimensions are flattened into 2. Kind of weird.

Dimensions are labeled by how many axes they either have.
For example, Dimension 0 has no spacial planes, therefore zero axes.
Dimension 1 has no spacial planes, but one axis that moves along a linear plane.
Dimension 2 has 1 spacial plane, and now two axes moving perpendicular to each other.
Dimension 3 has technically only 2 spacial planes, but three axes, all of which are perpendicular.

Dimension 4 is pretty complicated. Dimension 4 has 4 spacial planes, one set of 2 being Dimension 3, and the other being an exact copy of Dimension 3.
Dimension 4 has four axes, one of which does not interact with Dimension 3 at all. In fact, try this: Take a piece of paper and draw a triangular pyramid. ...Ok? Jeez, that's it? Needs some work... anyway, now label the vertices of this pyramid. How many are there? ...4? Ok, that's good. Now, draw a triangular pyramid with 5 vertices. ...What? Impossible you say? It's not, really. Just put 5 vertices on your paper in a manor that makes sense, and connect one vertex at a time to the other 4. Congratulations! You just drew a 4 Dimensional object... on a 2 Dimensional plane... Before you ask, the 4th axis is a cross section between the 4 planes.

So Dimensions are called what they are by the amount of axes they have. There is a reason for them to be in order.

While your points do stand for the 3 dimensions of space, time is a distinct dimension, as you state in the video. Therefore, while you can't categorise the space dimensions as a "first", "second", or "third", we CAN define space to be the first three dimensions, in which case we can say that time IS the fourth dimension.

If you don't see what I mean, imagine if there was a race where the first three people to finish all finished at exactly the same time, followed by a fourth person who is slower, but does not finish at the same time as anybody else. The first three drivers would all be awarded a joint first place - we can't categorise them into a first, second, and third - but the next driver is still awarded fourth place. In this case, the first three drivers can be thought of as space, whereas the fourth is time.

we just call the dimensions the "first dimension", "second dimension", and so on just so that we CAN tell them apart. This does not mean that the "first dimension" is the actual first dimension.

You have a piece of paper, and you draw a line. What do you have? the first dimension. It could be a vertical line, a horizontal line, or a diagonal line. Height, length, or width it doesn't matter, it is the first dimension. now you have a man sitting on a bench. You have the second dimension. Now you have defined length and height. Draw a tree in the background to give the picture depth, and there's your third dimension. Now the man gets off the bench to get an apple. When he leaves the bench, another man appears into the picture and sits on the bench. In what other way is it possible for him to get there than crossing into the fourth dimension known as time. It took time for the first man to walk towards the apple, and it took time for the second man to walk to the bench. There's your four dimensions.

Meaning is, to a large degree, use. We have conventionally used 'fourth dimension' to refer to time. It's not at all wrong to call time 'the fourth dimension'. That use arose in the context of adding time as a dimension to the classic 3 spatial dimensions, which no one would have done unless a causal relationship between time and space was observed. SO, of course, there is a fourth dimension.

Seeing in three dimensions would be if you could look at the face of an object and see it's width. If you look directly at one side of something, you don't see its width at all (think a coin flat on a desk, and look straight down at it; you don't see how thick it is). Our brains see light/shadows and things of that nature and interpret it as the width. This is how two dimensional paintings can be made to look 3D: by emulating shadows

0D- 1 point no lines

2D- 4 points 4 lines
3D 8 points 12 lines
And 4D would be 16 points X lines (There is no pattern)

A 3D cube can contain an infinite number of 2D planes, but only because they're infinitely thin. That doesn't give the 3D cube infinite mass, does it? We use infinitely small slices of things all the time to figure out finite areas and volumes - it's integral calculus. Any 4D hypervolume that intersects our world would just allow us to observe the 3D cross section at that point.

We also get depth information from the difference between what each of our eyes see. In addition, we sometimes will move our head around slightly to enhance that information when necessary. If there were a ball that grew at the same rate that it was moving away from me and I was wearing an eyepatch, then I would move slightly to aid my brain in processing the visual information to verify whether the ball was growing larger or moving away or both.

At least that's a possible way to understand relativity. So the time-dimensions are not at all different from the space-dimensions - just as the forward/backward dimension isn't different from the left/right dimension when walking on a plain - it's just the direction you are currently moving in.

It's the same with time. Time is the direction we move into - with lightspeed. If different objects move in slightly different time-directions, they start to drift relative to each other through what we call space. If you're near lightspeed, the difference in direction is so big, that there is no longer just a diversion proportional to the difference in angle, but also a significant difference in the distance you travel in what another object perceives as time, following pythagors/sinusfunctions

And about the 3+1 dimensions I was just giving and everyday example to contextualize what I was meaning with my comment, obviously dimensions are just an abstract idea, vectors as I said, that help physicist and many other scientist work in a space given, say our universe or whatever you'd like to study, as you probably know there are theories in string theory or high mathematics that work with a n-dimensional space -n being greater than 4-.

... for example in algebra the dimension of a space is given by the number of vectors that are independent to each other -and that the combination of them form the whole space those vectors are contained in-.

But you have understand that dimensions aren't in fact unique, what makes them unique is the fact that 'coexist' n dimensions in a space, whatever those dimensions are, what I mean to say is that you could have what you understand as of 'second dimension' and still be only able to 'draw' lines, the ability to 'draw a cube' comes from the fact that at least two dimensions coexist with each other, you need to interpretate dimensions as, for example, lineal independent vectors...

Lucky for us, we live in an age of science, when the unknown is welcomed as the next frontier for exploration!

I think if we discussion dimensions in terms of change in the previous dimension, we can dodge the question of "what units are these dimensions made of". The problem arises because we call the first three dimensions spatial dimensions.

Example: (assumes all dimensions are infinite)
0 dimension = spot point
1 dimension = mechanism of change in the spot point = a line
2 dimension = change in a line = a plane
3 dimension = change in a plane
4 dimension = change in a 3rd dimensional object
etc.

..and even then it's still relative. your "x" (left/right) dimension is  a different one from the "x" dimension of a person standing "left" from you, facing your side. their "x" dimension (left/right) is yours "z" dimension (forward/back), your "x" dimension (your left/right) is theirs "z" dimension (forward/back). it's all always relative to something. got it?

..what you consider to be "first", "second" and "third" dimension depends on the context in which you imagine them. if you imagine the first dimension as a vertical line, then it's going to be up/down. you can then imagine "second" dimension as being either left/right or towards you/away from you. but if you imagine the "first" one as being horizontal line, then the "second" one can either be up/down or away/towards. do you understand? the naming of the dimensions is only by convention..

This is an incredibly pointless semantic argument. Of course there's no intrinsic property of time that makes it come "after" our three spatial dimensions. But since we generally take "dimensions" to mean "spatial dimensions", it makes sense that we'd call our one time dimension the "fourth" dimension, because we talk about it later. It's not a *physics* reason for calling it fourth, it's a *human* reason--but it's reason enough, and the title of your video is misleading and wrong as a result.

Think of dimensions as tools in a toolbox, rather than a chaotic array.

Don't we label dimensions in the order in which they appear?  A point is zero-dimensional - it has no length, width or depth.  A line is one dimensional - it has length, but no width or depth (therefore length is the first dimension).  A square is two-dimensional with length and width, but no depth (making width the second dimension), and a cube is three dimensional with length, width and depth, making depth the third.  The time dimension can be separate, as any of these can be placed in time.

Say you're holding an unmarked, mono-colored cube in your palm. You measure the width, the length, and the height of said cube. You then take the cube, and lob it into the air. As this cube spins and rotates, you watch it. And on it's descent,  you catch it. When you once again hold it in your palm, you repeat the measurements. There is a very distinct possibility that what you measured as width before is now length, or height. We have no basis for a specific angle of perception, he's saying.

Actually, it's not correct to say there are three special dimensions and one time dimension. Just as it makes no sense to ask which dimension is the third spacial dimension, it makes no sense to ask which dimension is the time dimension. A vector can be space-like or time-like, but there's no one canonical direction that is time-like. That's what special relativity is about.

Matter is everything with volume, mass isn't strictly related nor is a defining feature of matter. Mass is the amount of inertia an object has, and it changes with speed, according to special relativity. Rest mass, the inertia of an object when its momentum is 0, is what we say is mass. Photons have no rest mass, which means they have no inertia, and there's the reason for them always traveling at light speed. All you can do is change the amount of energy in a photon, which results in colors.

A dimension is a way to measure something. Take for instance a square. The dimensions of a square are its length across--> Width, and its length from bottom to top-->Height. Well, you had partly right and partly wrong. As you say, you can't say which direction which is the first dimension. BUT... we have actually numbered the axes.

x = The first space dimension
y = The second space dimension
z = The third space dimension
t = The first time dimension, the fourth dimension
w = The fourth space dimension, the fifth dimension

The xyz-room is the "space" with 3 dims, the xyzt-room is what we call "spacetime". The w-axis is an axis pointing OUTSIDE our 3 dim. space.
